Andrew Serff wrote:
>
> I want to have a post processor update my own database with the
> location of the ARC file that was written for the current crawl (i.e.
> for each URI). Is there a way to determine this location?
>




Are you asking if you can insert a processor into the crawler at the 
'postprocessor' stage to insert the ARC file name a particular download 
was written to out to a remote database?  If so, the answer is no.  The 
necessary information is not available at the postprocessor stage, not 
without changing the ARCWriter so it adds the name of the current ARC 
file to the CrawlURI object so this is info is available later in the 
processing chain.

Or are you asking about post-processing ARCs after a crawl is done to 
load a database table with a key of URI and a value of the name of the 
ARC file that URI was written too?  If you are asking the latter, this 
is fairly straight-forward.  You would write a program that would read 
all ARCs made by a crawl.  Foreach, you would iterate over its contents 
and per URI, you would write out to the database your findings.  See 
http://crawler.archive.org/articles/developer_manual/arcs.html for more 
on ARCs, their format and available readers.

> I also don't know much about the ARCs. Do they contain an entire
> site, or just one page and all it's associated files (images, etc).
> If it can have multiple pages in it, it might change what I'm doing.
>




Default configuration writes downloads randomly to one of a small set of 
open ARC files. 

Best way to answer the above question on whats in an ARC, if the above 
cited link does not answer your question, is to crawl and then look at 
their contents.
St.Ack


>
> Let me know if anyone can help! Thanks!
> Andrew
>
